pullRequest.body:
We prove that the category structure defined in `CategoryTheory/Sums/Basic` satisfies a universal property that exhibits it as the binary coproduct of categories. In practive, this means that we construct an equivalence of categories `(A ⊕ A') ⥤ B ≌ (A ⥤ B) × (A' ⥤ B)`, which we characterize via its compositions in both directions with `Sum.inl_`, `Sum.inr_`, `Prod.fst` and `Prod.snd`.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> List.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

I was unsure whether or not this should go in a separate new file in the `CategoryTheory/Sum` directory, as it brings the product as import, but it seems that this file was almost never imported anyways, so that it would be harmless to keep fragmentation to a minimum here.

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

### PR summary [86c2a7912f](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/22278/commits/86c2a7912f88fe3cb02ec9b1d1f64dd99a6bb1f7)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.CategoryTheory.Sums.Products` (new file)|298|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ functorEquiv`
`+ functorEquivFunctorCompFstIso`
`+ functorEquivFunctorCompSndIso`
`+ functorEquivInverseCompWhiskeringLeftInLIso`
`+ functorEquivInverseCompWhiskeringLeftInRIso`
`+ functorEquiv_unit_app_app_inl`
`+ functorEquiv_unit_app_app_inr`
`+ ofNatIsoWhiskerLeftInlInr`
`+ ofNatIsoWhiskerLeftInlInr_hom`
`+ ofNatIsoWhiskerLeftInlInr_inv`
`+ ofNatTransWhiskerLeftInlInr`
`+ ofNatTransWhiskerLeftInlInr_comp`
`+ ofNatTransWhiskerLeftInlInr_id`
`+ sum'`
`+ sum'_app_inl`
`+ sum'_app_inr`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

I added constructors for natural transformations of functors out of a sum, as well as trivial simp lemmas that were missing in `Functor.sum'`. This was enough to speed up the autotactic proofs on `functorEquiv`. I added as well the trivial `simp` lemmas for `functorEquiv` (at least those for which the one generated by `simps` were unpleasant due to match arms).
Since it came up here as well as in #22281, I refactored `CategoryTheory.Sums` to allow different universes in #22976.

```suggestion
/-- The equivalence between functors from a sum and the product of the
```
Let's make sure the docstring here describes the distinction between this one and the one on `sum`. Currently, these two are exactly the same.
Is not it possible to have completely independent universes here?
Same issue as in #22281: the category structure on the sum is only defined when both categories live in the same universe, and it looks like it is a bit of a pain to generalize.
It seems the category structure could be generalized to a category in `max v_1 v_2` at the cost of sprinkling ULifts everywhere. Is this really desirable?

I'm not convinced the generalisation is worth it, particularly so because it makes the description of homs in the new category awkward: we can just ulift the two input categories from `v_1` and `v_2` to `max v_1 v_2` and take the sum there, now that they match.
I believe the comment section of #22976 would be a more appropriate place to discuss this now that it is submitted.
Some of these lemmas are already proven `by dsimp`, so that I do not think we need them. I would suggest removing those that can be proven `by dsimp` and keeping the others.
The new code should probably go in a separate file `CategoryTheory.Sums.Products`.

pullRequest.title: feat(CategoryTheory/Sums/Basic): functors out of `Sum`

source.title: feat(CategoryTheory/Sums/Associator): compatibility of products and sums associators

nodes.body: I added constructors for natural transformations of functors out of a sum, as well as trivial simp lemmas that were missing in `Functor.sum'`. This was enough to speed up the autotactic proofs on `functorEquiv`. I added as well the trivial `simp` lemmas for `functorEquiv` (at least those for which the one generated by `simps` were unpleasant due to match arms).
